We present here some preliminary results on cobalt-containing heterogeneous catalysts for the selective synthesis Of C, - C6 alcohols from carbon monoxide and hydrogen. The optimal composition range in the systems Cu/Co/Cr or Al/alkali canon is discussed. The preparation procedure is shown to have a determining effect on the final selectivity towards alcohols. Using coprecipitation of the metal nitrates by alkali carbonate, the different steps of catalyst preparation are examined and correlated to the catalyst activity. Stability of this type of catalyst is assessed by some duration tests. Finally, the role of the different components of the catalyst and some hypotheses on reaction mechanism are discussed. Introduction The selective production of CZhydrocarbons or oxygenated compounds remains one of the main goals of syntheses from carbon oxides and hydrogen. Such a production may be achieved using either heterogeneous or homogeneous processes. Both types of processes have been developed industrially, namely Fischer-Tropsch synthesis on iron oxide at the Sasol plant in South Africa [1j , isobutyl alcohol synthesis on alkalinized zinc chromite mixed oxides [2j, the so-called Mobil process on highly siliceous shape selective zeolites, [3, 41 and methanol carbonylation to acetic acid on rhodium-based soluble catalysts, `he Monsanto process [5] . None of these processes is entirely satisfactory with respect to activity and/or selectivity, except for methanol carbogylation which is hampered by rhodium availability. In choosing a new heterogeneous route to light (CI - C6} alcohols (and/ or hydrocarbons, I.F.P_ was guided by the following considerations: - operating conditions should be comparable to those used for methanol synthesis; high pressures above 15 MPa should be avoided. This condition precludes the type of catalyst classically .used for isobutyl alcohol synthesis; 0304-5102/82(000-3-00001$02-^. 5 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 242 - starting from methanol, light alcohols are produced via a molecular mechanism with good selectivity using cobalt-based homogeneous catalysts; in contras;, no direct route to light olefins has been demonstrated using homogeneous catalysts. We have thus chosen alcohol rather than hydrocarbon synthesis, on cobalt-based catalysts. A direct synthesis from carbon monoxide and hydrogen being looked for, these catalysts should in fact be cobalt-modified methanol synthesis catalysts. The following points will be described in this paper: the choice of precise elemental composition; preparation routes and physicochemical characterization of precursors, activated and steady-state catalysts; catalytic properties; aging under normal reaction conditions; and evaluation of reaction products. Experimental Preparation of precursors Two procedures are used: decomposition of a homogeneous precursor, and coprecipitation with sodium carbonate. (a) Decomposition of a homogeneous precursor- Complexation with a alcohol polyacics as described by Marcilly [6] and Courty et al. [7] is used. The organic acid (citric, malic, c, glycollic, lactic) is added to the metal nitrate solution until an acid/metal ratio of 0.5 - 2 eq. g. H`/1/rt M" is reached. The solution is first evaporated under vacuum, and the glassy X-ray-amorphous material thus obtained is air calcined to yield the mixed oxide. The alkalinization is normally included in the initial composition. (b) Coprecipitation. Precipitation of the metal nitrates (copper, cobalt II, chromium III: aluminium, zinc) in 0.5 - 1.5 M aqueous solutions is effected with a 0.5 - 1.5 M alkali metal carbonate solution under controlled and constant pH conditions at temperatures between 293 and 363 K. The precipitate is subsequently dried, calcined, and an alkalinization step is included in tile process flow scheme; Actiuation of catalysts The precursors are fast reduced by diluted hydrogen (PEI, < 0.1 MPa) at 433 - 573 K_ Further reduction may be carried out at higher pressures, using hydrogen or hydrogen-carbon monoxide mixtures. Start-up arid test The catalysts are tested in a high pressure microreactor, of capacity 10 60 cm', operating up to 12 MPa_ After to situ reduction, pressures are adjusted to the standard conditions (6 MPa, H,/CO = 2) and the temperature is slowly raised to 523 - 583 K_ Material balances are effected every 12 h_ The average yield varies between 0.08 - 0.2 g. g 1 cat. h-'. 2?3 Physicochemical characterization of catalysts (a) Local elemental composition is established at the micron level using a Ca-mebax microanalyzer, and at the nanometer level a Vacuum Generators HB5 STEM equipped with a Kevex X-ray emission energy dispersive analyzer. (b) Reduction is followed quantitatively using catharometric detection of hydrogen. (c) X-ray diffraction patterns are obtained with a Philips diffractometer PW 1050/25. Local electron diffractions of selected zones ranging from several microns to 2 nm can be acquired, using a modified microdiffraction facility on the liB5 [8] . (d) Catalytic properties, apart from alcohol synthesis itself, are evaluated, using methanol conversion as a test reaction (0.1 or 2.3 MPa, 4 73 - 673 K). Separation of reaction products After condensation at 288 K, the gas and liquid phases are analyzed offline by GC using 3 columns (molecular sieve, Porapak , and a methyl siliconecoated capillary column). Detailed analysis of the liquid phase is obtained using a GC-1i1S coupling IMP 5985 B. Results Choice o f elemental composition 'two systems have been systematically examined, using coprecipitation as the main preparation procedure: Cu0/Co0/Cr203 and Cu0/COO/AI203 (optionally Zn0) both alkalinized with K and/or Na. Figure 1 gives the selectivity observed as a function of precursor composition for the chromium-containing system. In the copper-rich field, methanol is obtained as the main product, and the activity goes through a maximum for Cu/Co ^- 4 - 5, Cu/Cr - 2 - 3. It is worth noting that small amounts of cobalt yield very active (yield > 0.5 gig ' cat. h-') and selective methanol synthesis catalysts. Chromium-rich compositions show logy activity (yield< 0.1 gig 1 cat. h-'), but selectivity to methanol is high even at high Co/Cu atomic ratios. Fischer-Tropsch catalysts are obtained in the cobaltrich field, the main product under standard conditions being methane. For intermediate compositions, especially in the field defined by 1 < Cu/Co < 3, Co/Cr > 0.5, a mixture of light alcohols Cy.- C6iS obtained with hydrocarbons Ct - C6 as byproducts. For fixed operating conditions, the higher alcohol (CZ OH) yield increases with the Co/Cu ratio. Increasing the Or/Co ratio decreases the overall activity and increases the selectivity to methanol. Finally, no selective catalyst can be obtained without alkalinization; in the absence of alkali cation, uncontrolled metdtanation occurs below 563 K. In tote CuO/COO/AI203 (+ Zn0) system, the observed trends are very similar. With optimal Cu/Co/AI/Zn/Na composition, typical results given in `Fable 1 are obtained. With these catalysts, activities up to 0.2 gig ' cat. h-1 are reached at moderate temperatures (below 583 K). Eac_i of them follows a Schulz-Flory distribution. Discussion Let us consider first the nature of the active sites, in a catalyst of composition CuO/COO/A'203/Na20. Concerning cobalt, it may be concluded that cobalt must be partly combined in a spinel structure in the precursor. Fn the activated catalyst, metallic cobalt must be present either pure or alloyed with copper; cobalt aluminzte or chromite substoichiometric in cobalt is inactive for higher alcohol synthesis. The role of copper is first to yield an active phase (Cur aluminate or chromite, according to [I1] ) for methanol synthesis, It also activates cobalt reduction and may modify metallic cobalt by alloying (though the solubility of copper in bulk cobalt is limited). The alkali cation first suppresses acidity, thus preventing alcohol dehydration and any Mobil-type reaction- However, it is well known t-hat alkalinization alone of a methanol synthesis catalyst yields a-n isobutanol synthesistype catalyst [2, 12] . Part of the alcohol production may result, from this type of modified methanol catalyst. Finally, the alkali ration may modify the electronic properties of cobalt, in the same manner as potassium oxide in fused iron oxide Fischer`Tropsch catalysts. Concerning the reaction mechanism, an important question is whether the alcohols are derived from a classical FischerTropsch mechanism or if they are formed via a mechanism similar to methanol homologation on cobalt carbonyl. The first hypothesis is supported by two facts: the Schulz-Flory distribution is followed; and alcohol and hydrocarbons appear in parallel, the a parameters for both Schulz-Flory distributions being the same. The production of oxygenated compounds by a Fischer-Tropsch-like process implies that carbon monoxide is at least partly chemisorbed and incorporated non-dissociatively. Assuming that the Schulz-Flory distribution is followed for all molecular weights, it is possible to predict the production of heavy products (for instance C=o) relative to the production of light hydrocarbons (and light 2lcohoIs). It can be verified that, with the a values found for light products distribution, the C'o production will be reasonable and allow for good catalyst stability. Such computations clearly show the advantage in producing a!'cohols, not hydrocarbons, as not too high values of a (i.e. rather high yields of methanol) must be reached in order to minimize the production of heavy products. 254 Conclusions Synthesis of a C I - C6 alcohol mixture from carbon monoxide and hydrogen can be achieved using cobalt-copper based catalysts. With welldesigned preparation procedures, it has proved possible to reduce classical Fischer-Tropsch activity and to enhance alcohol selectivity. Productivity of about 0.2 g.g ' cat. h' may be r--ached with a 60 - 809o selectivity to C1 - C6 alcohols and a C20H/C20H + C10H ratio higher than 6090. The preparation procedure is ver1 critical for the final selectivity, inadequate procedures leading to Fischer-Tropsch-like catalysts. Much work has been and is still to be done to improve the catalyst properties and to understand from a fundamental point of view the nature of the active sites as well as the reaction mechanism. coredata.dc:description: In addition to developing its own C1-C6 alcohol production process and catalyst, the Institut Français du Pétrole has undertaken some fundamental studies on the genesis of mixed oxide precursors for CO hydrogenation. We present here some preliminary results on cobalt-containing heterogeneous catalysts for the selective synthesis of C1-C6 alcohols from carbon monoxide and hydrogen. The optimal composition range in the systems Cu/Co/Cr or Al/alkali cation is discussed. The preparation procedure is shown to have a determining effect on the final selectivity towards alcohols. Using coprecipitation of the metal nitrates by alkali carbonate, the different steps of catalyst preparation are examined and correlated to the catalyst activity. Stability of this type of catalyst is assessed by some duration tests. Finally, the role of the different components of the catalyst and some hypotheses on reaction mechanism are discussed.
coredata.dc:title: C1-C6 alcohols from synthesis gas on copper-cobalt catalysts
